title: How to Play Cho Dai Di

steps.headline: Deal all 52 cards (excluding the Jokers) to the 4 players.
Learn the order of the cards.
Begin the game with the player who has the 3 of Diamonds.

Use it to form combinations such as the following (in ascending order):-Single card{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c2\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c2\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}
steps.description:
Pairs{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c6\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c6\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} If they are of the same number, the pair with the higher suit wins. e.g. 9Spades+9Diamonds trumps 9Hearts+9Clubs 3 of a kind{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/71\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/71\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet3.jpg\/v4-760px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} If they are of the same number, the pair with the higher suit wins. 5 Cards (in ascending order of value){"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/99\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet4.jpg\/v4-460px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/99\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet4.jpg\/v4-760px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Ascending (of different suit)Value based on the last card in the set. Therefore, in 2-3-4-5-6, the 2 is the smallest card and the 6 the largest. 5 of the same suit Value based on suit. e.g. 3-5-8-J-K of Spades trumps 9-J-Q-K-A of Diamonds 3 of a kind + 2 of a kind Value of the combination is based on the value of the 3 of a kind e.g. 8-8-8-5-5 trumps 3-3-3-2-2 even though the latter contains two 2s 4 of a kind + any other card The value of the combination is based on the value of the 4 of a kind Ascending of the same value e.g. 5-6-7-8-9 of Spades or J-Q-K-A-2 of Diamonds

steps.headline: Play a combination containing the 3 of Diamonds.
Continue putting down combinations of the same sort with a higher value around the circle.
steps.description: e.g 3-3-3-4-4 followed by 5-5-5-3-3 then 7-7-7-2-2 and whatever combination of the same sort.

steps.headline: Wait for the turn to go back to the last person who put down cards.
steps.description: He/She has the choice of whatever new combination to put down. This is a major part of the strategy as you should constantly try to have the upper-hand.

steps.headline: Win the game by being the person who finishes their cards first.

text:
Deal all 52 cards (excluding the Jokers) to the 4 players. Learn the order of the cards. The smallest suit is the Diamonds, followed by the Clubs, then the Hearts and finally the Spades. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2a\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2a\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} The smallest denomination card is the 3 going up to the Ace. The 2 is the biggest card. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a1\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a1\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Therefore, the 3 of Diamonds is the smallest card and the largest is the 2 of Spades. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/58\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/58\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet3.jpg\/v4-760px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Begin the game with the player who has the 3 of Diamonds. Use it to form combinations such as the following (in ascending order):-Single card{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c2\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c2\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Pairs{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c6\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c6\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} If they are of the same number, the pair with the higher suit wins. e.g. 9Spades+9Diamonds trumps 9Hearts+9Clubs 3 of a kind{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/71\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/71\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet3.jpg\/v4-760px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} If they are of the same number, the pair with the higher suit wins. 5 Cards (in ascending order of value){"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/99\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet4.jpg\/v4-460px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/99\/Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet4.jpg\/v4-760px-Play-Cho-Dai-Di-Step-4Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Ascending (of different suit)Value based on the last card in the set. Therefore, in 2-3-4-5-6, the 2 is the smallest card and the 6 the largest. 5 of the same suit Value based on suit. e.g. 3-5-8-J-K of Spades trumps 9-J-Q-K-A of Diamonds 3 of a kind + 2 of a kind Value of the combination is based on the value of the 3 of a kind e.g. 8-8-8-5-5 trumps 3-3-3-2-2 even though the latter contains two 2s 4 of a kind + any other card The value of the combination is based on the value of the 4 of a kind Ascending of the same value e.g. 5-6-7-8-9 of Spades or J-Q-K-A-2 of Diamonds Play a combination containing the 3 of Diamonds. Continue putting down combinations of the same sort with a higher value around the circle. e.g 3-3-3-4-4 followed by 5-5-5-3-3 then 7-7-7-2-2 and whatever combination of the same sort. Wait for the turn to go back to the last person who put down cards. He/She has the choice of whatever new combination to put down. This is a major part of the strategy as you should constantly try to have the upper-hand. Win the game by being the person who finishes their cards first.
